 Annex B Page 1 Statement of Irrigation Development Policy TANZANIA LETTER OF IRRIGATION DEVELOPMENT POLICY Background The Government Policy of economic liberalization and the efforts under structural adjustment policy in Tanzania have had a positive impact on the agricultural sector. The Government in addition to the devaluation of Tanzania currency, has liberalized the foreign exchange market which has improved competitiveness in international markets, thereby reviving the export sector. The Government has liberalized the marketing of food and cash crops and the procurement and distribution of inputs. Prompt cash payments to farmers for crops is now possible and this has improved farmers' incomes and provided incentives to increase production. In the past, the institutional structure of the agricultural sector was dominated by parastatal organizations and cooperatives, directed by the Government. Now the Government is phasing out its role in direct production, marketing, processing, divesting itself of its parastatals and shifting to provision of basic social and infrastructure services to the economy. The Government is therefore creating an enabling environment for full participation of the private sector while progressively reducing its involvement in direct production. This initiative emphasizes an agricultural production system where incentives are determined more by the market forces and less by direct Government intervention. The development of such an institutional structure will promote and sustain an enabling environment for growth in agricultural production, trade and investment leading to achievement of national objectives of: (i) increasing rural incomes; (ii) enhancing food security; (iii) achieving export growth, and (iv) conserving the environment. The institutional structure for supporting development of the agricultural sector should be adjusted to ensure; (i) the provision of an adequate legal and regulatory framework for enhanced agricultural production; (ii) that the Government role is limited to core functions; and (iii) that the domestic incentive systems and resource allocation systems are directed to promote and facilitate high quality performance in discharging the core functions. In the agricultural sector, the Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives is going through rationalization and streaming processes focusing only on strategic core functions such as research, extension, training, control of epidemic diseases, policy formulation and management, monitoring, information and regulation. In parallel the government continues with a major reform initiative whereby it would limit its role to the core function of governance. The private sector is being encouraged to undertake all commercial activities such as input procurement and distribution, crop marketing and processing, etc. Rationalization and streamlining is continuing at the regional level aiming at transfer of resources from the regions to the districts and making district administration more community based.
 Annex B Page 2 The National Agricultural Policy The National Agricultural Policy is being reviewed to incorporate the current macro and sectoral vision. The main objectives of the National Agricultural Policy are: - to ensure basic food security for the nation to improve national levels of nutrition by increasing the output, quality and availability of food commodities. - to improve standards of living in the rural areas through increased income generation from agricultural and livestock production, processing and marketing. - to increase foreign exchange earning for the nation by encouraging the production and increased exportation of cash crops, livestock products, other agricultural surpluses, by- products and residues. - to produce and supply raw materials, including industrial crops, livestock by-products and residues for local industries, while also expanding the role of the sector as a market for industrial outputs through the application of improved production, marketing and processing technologies. - to develop and introduce new technologies which increase the productivity of labor and land. - to develop human resources within the sector in order to increase the productivity of labor and to improve ability, awareness and morale. - to provide support services to the agricultural sector, which cannot be provided efficiently by the private sector. - to enhance the access of women to land, credit, education and information. Agriculture Development Strategy Focus Agriculture plays a dominant role in the national economy. Despite this role, much of its production potential remains unexploited. Of the total 43 million ha of land suitable for agricultural production, only 6.3 million ha are under cultivation. Of cultivated land only 150,000 ha is under irrigation despite an irrigation potential estimated at 1,000,000 ha. The rest of cultivated land is left to erratic and unreliable rainfall. Irrigation infrastructure is one of the key areas where the small farmer needs Government support. The development of irrigation systems is a vital component of the agricultural development strategy because irrigated food crop production improves food security particularly in the drought seasons and in areas of inadequate rainfall. Again properly managed irrigation schemes provide sustainable increases in small farmer productivity and income thereby contributing to poverty alleviation. Also, through irrigation high value crops (vegetables, flowers, etc) can be produced under controlled conditions required for international markets. This has led the Government to adopt the National Irrigation Development Plan (NIDP). The Plan comprises a management and decision making framework based on comprehensive ranking of schemes within each sectoral management unit. The plan concentrates on the following: (i) removal of remaining constraints on the sector through implementation of various programs such as institutional reform, private
 Annex B Page 3 sector strengthening, cost sharing, cost recovery, research, devolution of operation and maintenance responsibilities to water users in the schemes; (ii) detailed master planning studies; and (iii) construction of the irrigation schemes. Government involvement in the financing of irrigation infrastructure is justified when (i) the beneficiaries are poor, (ii) the beneficiaries are unable to mobilize the necessary resources themselves; (iii) technical standards and economic viability criteria are met; and (iv) there is a need for social and organizational development to ensure effective scheme management. NIDP priorities for public sector investment are as follows: - rehabilitation and upgrading of traditional smallholder irrigation schemes - construction of schemes based on water harvesting techniques, and - construction of new smallholder schemes where there is little or no traditional irrigation schemes and where conditions aresuitable. Community sensitization and participation would be maximized as a precondition to financing the construction of irrigation infrastructure. As for private sector, NIDP simply sets out to facilitate, regulate and monitor its performance. Development Strategy for Irrigation For better natural resources management, the Government will ensure that the management of Tanzania's irrigation sector is based on the country's river or drainage basin and not on the political boundaries as has been the case in the past. The Government has reviewed the experience with irrigation projects and decided to greatly reduce its involvement at all levels of scheme implementation and management. The Government will: - In the case of new or existing privately owned and operated irrigation, the Government will be limited to encouraging private entrepreneurs to finance their own pre-investment studies, scheme design, construction and management of irrigation schemes using their own resources. The Government will provide the enabling environment and information, as well as issuing water rights, and regulating and monitoring natural resource exploitation. - Focusing its support on the development of smallholder irrigation schemes in areas of high production potential and high demand for irrigation facilities. The Government will provide assistance at the planning and design stage for smallholder irrigation schemes. Where appropriate, following work to improve community organization and management of the irrigation scheme, Government could finance construction of irrigation infrastructure. In this regard, Government would restrict its role to the supervision of construction. Actual construction work will be contracted out to private entrepreneurs. In all cases where it involved in the construction of irrigation facilities the Government will
 Annex B Page 4 give due consideration to land conservation and environmental problems, as well as the need of disadvantaged groups to gain access to good services, land resources and credit. In the smallholder sector farmer-irrigators will be encouraged to form water users associations, either based on traditional organizations or starting from scratch, for management of their schemes. In addition, they would be encouraged to form irrigation cooperatives as a step towards commercialization and participation in the market economy. The selection of irrigation schemes to receive Government support for upgrading will be based on: - confirmation that there is no environmental risk; - confirmation that there are adequate water resources for all stakeholders in the basin; - in the case of smallholder schemes, fully sensitized, organized and committed communities and a thorough participatory rural appraisal, or similar analysis; - feasibility studies which indicate technical and economic viability; - compatibility with the National Irrigation Development Plan and its supporting ranking system. The ranking process will reflect changing policies and priorities and lessons learned through continuous sector monitoring. As regards design of smallholder schemes requiring donor or Government support, labor based construction techniques will be favored and should be seen as an opportunity to use community labor, especially if suitable for gabion technology The operation and maintenance costs of the improved schemes will be met by the users except in case of major common infrastructure such as main canals or drains common to several schemes, which are beyond the capacity of members to operate. Suitable modalities for these cases have yet to be identified and will be based on further studyThe construction costs borne by the Government will have to be partly repaid by the users through a cost recovery mechanism. However, training in operation and maintenance of schemes by Water User Groups and Irrigation Cooperative Societies will be provided by the Government. The Government will ensure that support services, such as extension, inputs, credit, market information and irrigation schemes planning data are provided. To improve crop marketing the Government will be required to make sure that improved support infrastructure is in place. This includes on-farm storage, rural access roads and markets. Research geared to improving water management and crop productivity in the irrigation sector is an essential component.  Anna F Page 1 Pastoral Issues in the Usaneu Plain The Usangu Plains are the most important pastoral area in the Rufiji Basin. Some 22 percent of Usangu's population are livestock herders, whose collective holdings constitute some half a million cattle, 53,000 goats, 49,000 sheep, and 2,900 donkeys. Six different ethnic groups comprise the pastoral population of Usangu: the indigenous Sangu peoples, and the Ilparakuyo Maasai, Sukuma, Gogo, Barabaig, and Taturu peoples who immigrated to Usangu from other districts of Tanzania. Pastoral immigration into Usangu began in 1953, peaked in the 1970s, and continues on a small scale today. The livestock population of the Plains increased ten-fold between 1938 and 1993, in large part due to pastoral immigration. The vast majority of Usangu's livestock herders cultivate as well. Concurrent with pastoral immigration into Usangu has been large-scale immigration by cultivators from Tanzania's southern highlands. The last four decades have seen the spread of irrigated cultivation on the Usangu Plains. Immigrant cultivators have come seeking opportunities to engage in the commercial production of paddy rice. Irrigated rice production is also carried out on two State farms, and several donor-funded irrigation projects aiming to improve and develop smallholder production have been implemented in Usangu since the 1980s. Thus demands for land and water resources on the Usangu Plains have grown substantially since the 1950s, culminating in competition and conflict between herders and farmers over resource access, use, and control. Farming activities are concentrated in the southem portion of the Usangu Plains, while livestock herding takes place mainly in the central Plains. This paper assesses the relationships and interactions that currently prevail between pastoralists and other entities on the Usangu Plains, specifically peasant cultivators, State Farms, fishermen, conservationists, the natural environment, and the Utengule Swamp. The relevance of pastoralism on the Usangu Plains to the concerns of the River Basin Management and Smallholder Irrigation Improvement Project lies in four main areas. First, the River Basin Management component aims to equitably allocate water in the Rufiji Basin between different user groups. Thus it is important to assess water use by pastoralists, and to determine whether or not their water needs are being met. Second, the Usangu Plains are a likely target area for irrigation improvement under the Smallholder Irrigation Improvement component of the Project. Conflict between herders and farmers may be a constraint to irrigation improvement, calling for an analysis of herder-farmer conflict on the Plains, and how it might be mitigated. Third, the Utengule Swamp has been identified as an area deserving special study under the Project in order to better understand its role in the hydrology of the Great Ruaha sub-Basin. The Utengule Swamp is the single most important dry season grazing area on the Usangu Plains; the vast majority of the regional livestock herd concentrates in the Swamp between July and December each year. Thus it is important to better understand the impact of pastoralism on the Swamp, and conversely, the importance of the Swamp to the livestock economy of the Plains. Finally, it is important to assess project-related environmental concerns relating to pastoralism on the Usangu Plains. What are the direct and indirect impacts of pastoralism in Usangu on water quality and quantity in the Great Ruaha sub-Basin? What are the potential ecological consequences of Project-related activities for pastoralism? Water Use by Pastoralists Usangu's pastoralists rely on naturally-occurring water throughout the year. They do not manage water resources, or obstruct or divert water in Usangu's watercourses. Water is abundant and widespread throughout the rainy season and livestock obtain an adequate supply. During the dry season, most of Usangu's rivers dry up downstream, causing pastoralists to migrate and concentrate in areas where
 Annex F Page 2 perennial water is available. Many of Usangu's rivers once flowed perennially, but no longer do because their waters are used for dry season irrigation at the southern border of the Plains, their point of entry. Both people and livestock residing in the central Plains suffer from dry season water scarcity as a result of dry season irrigation activities. Fishermen who establish camps near the Great Ruaha River in the dry season occasionally block streams by building dams to concentrate fish populations, exacerbating water shortages for other users. In some areas, livestock have difficulty reaching watering points because there are no stock routes, making it necessary for animals to cross agricultural fields, which generates conflict between herders and farmers. It would be useful to undertake a survey under the River Basin Management Component of the Project to determine which of Usangu's watercourses dry up during the dry season, where, when, and why. Dry season irrigation activities should be prohibited if they prevent downstream users from obtaining sufficient water for domestic use. At the least, measures should be taken to ensure minimum flow levels in rivers that would accomodate the needs of downstream users and more equitably allocate dry season water between farmers and herders. Steps should be taken to ensure that irrigation water is returned to the rivers from which it originates. Fishermen should be prohibited from obstructing watercourses during the dry season. While this may appear disadvantageous to them in the short run, in the long run they will benefit from conservation of fish stocks. Livestock routes to watering points should be incorporated into village land use plans. It is not practical or justifiable to charge pastoralists water use fees for water consumed by livestock. It would be useful to appoint someone to the Rufiji Basin Water Board who could represent the perspective and needs of pastoralists in water allocation and management decisions. Conflicts between Pastoralists and Cultivators Conflict between herders and State Farns is minimnal. Herders rarely trespass on State property. However, herders living in the Kapunga area have suffered from the alienation of grazing land that took place when the State Farm was established. Those smallholder irrigation projects (the Kapunga Project and the Madibira Rice Project) that have or plan to develop new areas for irrigation will mnake it increasingly difficult for pastoralists to obtain sufficient dry season forage. Agricultural encroachment by peasant farmers onto Usangu's rangelands is essentially uncontrolled, and is facilitated by the current land tenure system. Grazing land on the Usangu Plains is open access. As pastoralists experience increasing resource scarcity due to the spread of agriculture, bush encroachment onto grasslands, and growing livestock populations, conflict arnong them, and between them and cultivators, escalates. Conflict between herders and farmers arises from two main sources: 1) livestock trespass on farns without permission and destroy crops and fields, and 2) farmers cultivate in areas that have been explicitly designated as grazing areas by village councils. Forage is scarce in the dry season. Crop stubble remaining on harvested fields is a desirable resource. Herders having large livestock herds - especially the Sukuma -- graze their animals on rice and maize stubble without pernission from farmers, often destroying remaining crops, irrigation canals and bunds, and damaging fields in the process. This phenomenon has led to violent conflict between the Sukuma and farmers and remains unresolved. Herders are desperate for dry season resources. The more those resources dwindle, the greater the conflict. Conversely, farmers in some villages experience land shortages for irrigation during the wet season and establish fields on lands that have been specifically set aside for grazing by village councils. Herders then suffer wet season pasture shortages, and have taken farmers to court.
 Annex F Page 3 Immigration into the Usangu Plains should be controlled to prevent increasing demographic pressure from exacerbating herder-farmer conflicts. Village Councils should be given well-defined powers to control settlement within village boundaries. Permission to settle should be based on the ability of villages to support additional livestock populations, and the availability of farmland. Additional land alienation in the Usangu Plains by the Tanzanian State should be discouraged. Smallholder irrigation improvement projects should emphasize improving existing irrigation schemes rather than developing new ones. Formal village demarcation and titling activities, and land use planning to formally designate cultivation and grazing zones with land titles verifying the boundaries of these areas would help to reduce herder-farmer conflict, and make individuals more accountable. Pastoralists would benefit from secure land tenure rights, which would in turn facilitate pastoral resource management and rangeland conservation. These activities could be undertaken under the auspices of the World Bank funded Forest Resources Management Project. It makes sense to collaborate in efforts to manage land and water within one geographic area. A special study of pastoral land tenure and resource use on the Usangu Plains would assist in this effort. Utengule Swamp The Utengule Swamp is ecologically important for its biodiversity values, its ecological functions, and its hydrological role within the Great Ruaha River system. It also has economic importance. The Swamp may have a major influence on the amount of water that flows into the Mtera Reservoir downstream, and that is available for hydropower generation. It may also help prevent sedimentation at the Reservoir. The Swamp is a potential source of foreign exchange generated through tourism and sport hunting. Finally, it supports the livestock economy of the Usangu Plains. Despite its ecological and economic importance, no scientific study of the Utengule Swamp has ever been undertaken. Thus its ecology and hydrology are poorly understood. T'he vast majon'ty of Usangu's pastoralists migrate to Utengule Swamp during the dry season and graze their animals there between July and December each year. The Swamp is the single most important dry season grazing area on the Usangu Plains, and the bulk of the regional livestock population concentrates there at this time of year. It is unclear what the ecological impact of pastoralism on the Utengule Swamp is. In 1963 some 500 sq. km. of the Swamp was designated as a Game Controlled area in order to preserve its dwindling wildlife populations. A proposal is currently under consideration to change the status of the Game Controlled Area to that of a Game Reserve, with some boundary alteration. Grazing and cultivation are permitted inside of Game Controlled Areas, but are prohibited inside of Game Reserves. If the Utengule Swamp becomes a Game Reserve, there will be dire consequences for Usangu's pastoralists. There is a proposal to conduct a special study of the Utengule Swamp as one component of the RBMSIIP Project because of its hydrological importance in the Rufiji Basin. The findings of this paper fully support this recommendation. A special study of Utengule Swamp should include a component that investigates the ecological impact of pastoralism on the Swamp, including examination of pastoral resource use, management, and tenure at the Swamp. This study should explore the possibility of managing Utengule Swamp as a Conservation Area, thereby accomodating the needs and goals of both conservationists and pastoralists.
 Annex F Page 4 Environmental Concerns Environmental concerns surrounding pastoralism in Usangu that are relevant to Project activities include the direct and indirect impact of pastoralism on water quantity and quality in the Ruaha sub-Basin, and the ecological effects of irrigation on pastoralism. The amount of water consumed by Usangu's livestock population has been calculated as 0.25 percent of the average annual flow into the Mtera Reservoir. Although the impact of livestock on water quantity is negligible, the impact of livestock on water quality may be significant. To my knowledge, no data exist on whether Usangu's water supply has been contaminated by livestock feces and thereby poses a threat to human health. Health risks from contaminated water would be particularly high during the dry season. These risks would most probably be localized on the Usangu Plains. Similarly, no data exist regarding the causal relationship between pastoralism and land degradation on the Usangu Plains, and whether livestock-induced degradation has an indirect effect on water quantity or quality in the region. Extensive bush encroachment on the Usangu Plains has been attributed to high stocking rates. Tlhe spread of irrigation on the Usangu Plains has caused a rise in the incidence of liver flukes, one of the leading causes of livestock morbidity and mortality in the region. Liver flukes occur in marshes, swamps, and areas of standing water. These habitats have increased as a result of poor drainage from irrigation schemes. The RBMSIIP can help to ameliorate this problem by improving drainage systems. Any pesticides or herbicides introduced as a part of the Smallholder Irrigation Improvement component may contaminate water supplies used by livestock. Pesticides and herbicides become concentrated in milk and meat, and pose a threat to both livestock and human health. If dams are built for purposes of water storage for irrigation activities, the natural flooding patterns of the Plains will be altered. Flooding on the Plains has a direct influence on livestock forage quality and quantity. If water storage facilities are built as a part of the Smaliholder Irrigation Improvement component, they will have a major affect on resource availability to livestock.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the River Basin Management and Smallholder Irrigation Improvement Project are to: (1) strengthen the Government's capacity to manage water resources and address water related environmental concerns both at the national level, and in the Rufiji and the Pangani river basins; and (2) improve irrigation efficiency of select smallholder traditional irrigation schemes in these two basins. The components of this project are: (1) river basin management, which includes the following activities: (i) strengthen national water resources management by reforming the regulatory framework to improve stakeholder participation in river basin management, strengthen the water rights concepts and management, increasing penalties and raising fees for water use, and improve information gathering and analytical capabilities at the national level; (ii) improve both the regulator capabilities and the information and resources monitoring capabilities at the basin offices in Rufiji and Pangani; and (iii) rehabilitate the hydrometric network in the Rufiji and Pangani basins; and (2) improvement of smallholder irrigation schemes in which the Government will assist in setting up farmer organizations, and provide financing for the improvement of infrastructure to be maintained and operated by water-user organizations.
